Award.AwardTitle: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Reproductive Sharing and Fitness in Cooperative Societies
Award.AbstractNarration: The mating system of the acorn woodpecker (Melanerpes formicivorus) is among the most complex of any vertebrate: groups consist of up to seven breeding males, as many as three reproductive females and a variable number helpers (offspring of previous years that remain on the natal territory and do not breed). Males compete to mate and females lay their eggs communally in the same nest. Breeders of the same sex are almost always close relatives, either siblings or parents and offspring. Previous work showed that joint-nesting groups of females, unlike males, share parentage equally. This project will determine the factors that influence reproductive sharing in acorn woodpecker societies by combining fieldwork on color-marked birds with modern molecular techniques to identify individuals that successfully produce young within social groups and to quantify their behavior. A primary goal of the project is to understand the fitness consequences of cooperative breeding and to integrate findings into the larger questions of the evolution and ecology of group living in highly social species, including humans.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The acorn woodpecker, a permanently territorial species common in the American Southwest, leads one of the most complicated social lives of any bird in the world. It is a "cooperative breeder," living in family groups that consist of multiple cobreeders of both sexes (a mating system known as polygynandry) along with offspring from prior years that help raise young at the communal nest. This project, a continuation of a long-term study of this species begun in 1971 in central coastal California, investigated several key aspects of the behavior of acorn woodpeckers, focusing on their altruistic behavior of provisioning young that are not their own offspring.

 One of the more important questions we focused on during the course of this grant was the question of what helpers gain out of forgoing breeding on their own and instead helping to raise what are generally younger siblings. One possibility is that they gain experience that enhances their own reproductive success later in life. Alternatively, they may be forced out of the group if they do not help. Our work failed to find support for either of these hypotheses.  Experiments and analyses demonstrated that chick provisioning by helpers reduces effort by other members of the group, however, which in conjunction with the prior results supports the hypothesis that the main benefit helpers gain by provisioning at nests is through facilitating reproduction by the breeders in the group. Since the breeders are usually close relatives, this suggests that kin selection is an important driver of this phenomenon.

Interestingly, the benefit that helpers provide varies significantly depending on both the sex of the helper and the ecological conditions--primarily the size of the autumn acorn crop--on which the birds are highly dependent. Male helpers have a strong, positive effect on reproductive success, but only following years of high acorn production. In contrast, female helpers have a small, barely positive effect that is independent of the size of the acorn crop. This is very different from what has been found in other cooperative breeders that have been studied.

We are currently investigating the factors driving these differences, which appear to be unrelated to the provisioning rates of the helpers. This once again raises the question of why helpers help--a key issue since helping behavior is one of the few clear examples of altruism observed in the animal world, and thus a better understanding of this behavior may help us to understand and to more effectively foster cooperative behavior within and among human societies.
